summary: I’m sorry but can we just talk about how some of the Stark children are basically following their ancestors? Jon - Manning the...
body:
I’m sorry but can we just talk about how some of the Stark children are basically following their ancestors?

Jon - Manning the Wall that Brandon the Builder built,
        - was killed trying to save his sister Arya, Brandon Stark was killed trying to
          save Lyanna Stark

Sansa - In the Vale with the House Royce, Beron Stark wed Lorra Royce 

Arya - The Mountain Clans are planning a revolt in her name, Rodrick Stark 
           wed Arya Flint

Bran - Beyond the Wall from where the First Men are from, the Starks come
           from the First Men

tags: a song of ice and fire
summary:
~Swords of Destiny: Sword & Sorcery sub-genre on A Song of Ice and Fire~
Robert E. Howard wasn't the creator of this fantasy...
body:
~Swords of Destiny: Sword & Sorcery sub-genre on A Song of Ice and Fire~

Robert E. Howard wasn’t the creator of this fantasy sub-genre. Like Lovecraft, he recognized that he was standing on the shoulders of geniuses and acknolwedged their contribution to his preferred medium and their influences which largely consisted of religious folklore and ancient history. He used an archaic style that echoed his Victorian predecessors. But here is where the similarities stop. Unlike Lovecraft who followed their Victorian predecessors’ line of reasoning more closely, Robert E. Howard chose to be a rebel even within their own circles by challenging the usual fantasy tropes. Like Lovecraft, he had a tough life and just as with every fiction writer, it’s almost impossible to disassociate his writing from his personal experiences.*

Towards the end of his life, Robert E. Howard took a grim view of the world that echoed H.P. Lovecraft but unlike his fellow writer whose stories also became bleaker, Howard’s remained just as violent with a pinch of hope added to them. Conan the Cimmerian or Conan the Barbarian (as modern audiences know him by) never falls into despair. When he comes face to face with the cosmic horrors that stalk the universe, he uses their logic against them. The same goes with Howard’s first war lord creation, Kull. In an introduction to “Kull: Exile of Atlantis”, a modern author calls Kull the “barbarian’s scholar” and the “scholars’ barbarian.” He is a little bit of both, much like his later creation set during the Stuart Era, Solomon Kane. His view of the world is shaped by his experiences. Unaware that he is meant for something greater, he goes on various quests until he fully embraces the responsibilities that have been thrust upon him by fate. Rather than becoming fate’s puppet like George R. R. Martin’s characters from A Song of Ice and Fire and the spin off novellas set in the same world, he still lives by his own rules.

It basically bottles down to “my way or the highway. I will embrace my destiny or whatever grand plan the gods have set out for me BUT I will do so if you agree to all of my conditions.”

While the TV show and the books are separate entities, given what we know about the first meeting between GRRM and D&D where the latter convinced him to adapt his epic saga into a series after they guessed correctly who Jon Snow’s mother was; we can infer that the ending we got to see on the silver screen will parallel that of the books. And given the science fiction and fantasy authors that have hugely influenced Martin, such ending should come to us as no big surprise. The only big difference will be the progression. Martin has said in an recent interview that he is this close to releasing the “Winds of Winter” which is the sixth and penultimate book in the Song of Ice and Fire series. He added that along with the last book (“Dreams of Spring”) will be a sum of 3000 pages or more. Martin knows what fans want but also what works better for his saga, and will give us an ending that will be as he always promised “bittersweet”. Daenerys’ actions will make more sense, and there will be more revealed regarding the sinister nature of the three-eyed-raven and by extension Bran than the superficial explanation we got on season 8. This also leads to a possibility that Dany’s death -if she is killed by Jon Snow- will lead to something more. Some fans have speculated that she will be revived after Bran is revealed to be the ultimate evil, fully embracing her true destiny (which was never to rule the seven kingdoms but fight Ice which to the red priests represents the nothingness); fire turned flesh as Kinvara said to Varys of her dragons.

If this were to happen, it would be bittersweet but also be a good way to end the saga. Everything comes full circle. What’s left after is a promise fo spring, and for mankind to start over.

But this also leads to an earlier point I made which is that as highly developed and multi-faceted as Martin’s characters are, they are left with no choice.

*Ask any author and they will tell you that their personal experiences influenced their writings one way or another. Robert E. Howard led an interesting but tragic life which I encourage my fellow geeks to read.

Images: Top, from left to right, Bran and Dany. Bottom, from left to right: fan art of Conan and Kull.

summary: Is Bran a Kwisatz Haderach? A Supreme Being/Savior? Some have compared Bran to the supreme being/chosen one from the Dune...
body:
Is Bran a Kwisatz Haderach? A Supreme Being/Savior?

Some have compared Bran to the supreme being/chosen one from the Dune novels. But is it a valid comparison?

No.

Here’s why: Whereas Leto and his father (the first KH) can see multiple futures and have lived multiple lives due to them unlocking the memories of ALL of their ancestors; they don’t just sit around waiting for their desired outcome to become a reality. There’s a lot of manipulation and deception on their part but this is done with them at the forefront instead of working behind the shadows to avoid danger.

Also, the future, as it is often shown, isn’t fixed; meaning that each choice we make leads to different outcomes which forces our protagonists to work harder to get their desired outcome. By contrast in Game of Thrones -and I suspect in the novels as well given Robert A. Heinlein’s influence on GRRM on this subject- time is a fixed point. You can’t undo the past nor change the future. Free will is an illusion. The ending of #GameofThrones also leaves you with the idea that maybe, just maybe, Bran is the greatest villain in all the history of Westeros. He tells Meera he’s not Bran anymore but then he goes back to embracing that identity after he’s named King. He tells Tyrion that’s the sole reason why he accompanied his sisters to Westeros, to be King.

The consciousness of the old gods of nature revered by the (COTF) children of the Forest, live within him. He’s the COTF revenge. But unlike the myriad of possibilities undone by the unpredictable nature of mankind in Dune, the future is set in this saga. Thus, dooming mankind to an eternity of subservience under this all-knowing nature vessel.

Furthermore, even with all the transference of consciousness that also occurs in Dune with the 2 KH, they don’t lose all of their humanity. Leto II becomes the God Emperor and goes on to rule the Known Universe for thousands of years but in spite of his new condition and super powers, he still feels. Unlike what was implied by the GOT ending, Paul and Leto’s objective when launching their Jihad wasn’t to take over all living things to aid the greedy Bene Gesserit (who were the initial movers and shakes behind their creation, much like the COTF with Bran and previous three-eyed-ravens); rather, it was to help humankind reach their true potential.

*It’s no secret that GRRM is a big science fiction buff. Most of his books are science fiction and one of his biggest influences from this genre is Robert A. Heinlein. For those of you who are new to his works; I’ll keep it short. Heinlein has written many works where he deals with the issue of time and free will. Characters who find out about their destiny or are offered the chance to escape whatever time loop they’re stuck on, find out they can’t because once they know their destiny, it can only mean that their future is set and will happen regardless of how much they fight against it.

Some have compared Bran to the supreme being/chosen one from the Dune novels. But is it a valid comparison?

No.

Here’s why: Whereas Leto and his father (the first KH) can see multiple futures and have lived multiple lives due to them unlocking the memories of ALL of their ancestors; they don’t just sit around waiting for their desired outcome to become a reality. There’s a lot of manipulation and deception on their part but this is done with them at the forefront instead of working behind the shadows to avoid danger.

Also, the future, as it is often shown, isn’t fixed; meaning that each choice we make leads to different outcomes which forces our protagonists to work harder to get their desired outcome. By contrast in Game of Thrones -and I suspect in the novels as well given Robert A. Heinlein’s influence on GRRM on this subject- time is a fixed point. You can’t undo the past nor change the future. Free will is an illusion. The ending of #GameofThrones also leaves you with the idea that maybe, just maybe, Bran is the greatest villain in all the history of Westeros. He tells Meera he’s not Bran anymore but then he goes back to embracing that identity after he’s named King. He tells Tyrion that’s the sole reason why he accompanied his sisters to Westeros, to be King.

The consciousness of the old gods of nature revered by the (COTF) children of the Forest, live within him. He’s the COTF revenge. But unlike the myriad of possibilities undone by the unpredictable nature of mankind in Dune, the future is set in this saga. Thus, dooming mankind to an eternity of subservience under this all-knowing nature vessel.

Furthermore, even with all the transference of consciousness that also occurs in Dune with the 2 KH, they don’t lose all of their humanity. Leto II becomes the God Emperor and goes on to rule the Known Universe for thousands of years but in spite of his new condition and super powers, he still feels. Unlike what was implied by the GOT ending, Paul and Leto’s objective when launching their Jihad wasn’t to take over all living things to aid the greedy Bene Gesserit (who were the initial movers and shakes behind their creation, much like the COTF with Bran and previous three-eyed-ravens); rather, it was to help humankind reach their true potential.

*It’s no secret that GRRM is a big science fiction buff. Most of his books are science fiction and one of his biggest influences from this genre is Robert A. Heinlein. For those of you who are new to his works; I’ll keep it short. Heinlein has written many works where he deals with the issue of time and free will. Characters who find out about their destiny or are offered the chance to escape whatever time loop they’re stuck on, find out they can’t because once they know their destiny, it can only mean that their future is set and will happen regardless of how much they fight against it.

summary: Still can't get over the ending
body:
Still can’t get over the ending

The fact that the leak was true, thinking it was joke after reading Bran would be named king and the North getting independence while Dorne and the Iron Islands remain in the kingdom. Thinking that Tyrion, the smartest man in Westeros, would never ever propose a claim as outrageous as this after having known how the game works, how the lords and ladies of Westeros minds revolve. It was a joke, right?

tags: I LOVE the thought of Bran being KITN
and I think D&D just heard he becomes King and made him King of the south
when his story is clearly rooted in the north
summary: hi, can I ask what your thoughts on bran are and why you think he’s going to end up king? to me it seemed like that ending came...
question: hi, can I ask what your thoughts on bran are and why you think he’s going to end up king? to me it seemed like that ending came out of nowhere and i’m looking for something to back it up
answer:
Bran becoming King is something I’ve always considered, but now I’m confident he becomes King in the North in the books.

If we take the show-verse, then yeah, it’s completely out of nowhere.

But the books carry just enough hints and foreshadowing that we can see how this becomes his endgame. But again, his throne is in the North.

The Fisher King

There was a theory posted ages ago about Bran as “The Fisher King.” I suggest a read, it’s a little long to paste here but I’ll try to summarise the key points that I think are relevant. Everything in italics is quoted from the original meta. The theory highlights parallels between mythical figures and the sources of their power. For the Fisher King (or King Arthur, who GRRM has compared Bran to), who draws his powers from the Holy Grail, the Starks’ are centred around the heart tree, around Winterfell.

“The Stark in Winterfell” is ASOIAF’s incarnation of the Fisher King, a legendary figure from English and Welsh mythology who is spiritually and physically tied to the land, and whose fortunes, good and ill, are mirrored in the realm. It is a story that, as it tells how the king is maimed and then healed by divine power, validates that monarchy. The role of “The Stark in Winterfell” is meant to be as its creator Brandon the Builder was, a fusion of apparent opposites: man and god, king and greenseer, and the monolith that is his seat is both castle and tree, a “monstrous stone tree.”

And it’s not just any Stark - the Stark in Winterfell is a title interchangeable with the one that rules it: “The Stark in Winterfell wanted Bael’s head…” “The Stark in Winterfell had to take a hand [in-stopping the Night’s Watch’s rebellion] -Jon, ASOS And then you’ve got Bran, who’s repeatedly referred as such. “I’m the Prince. I’m the Stark in Winterfell.” “You are the Stark in Winterfell, and Robb’s heir. You must look princely.” Together they garbed him as befit a lord. He was the Stark in Winterfell, his father’s son and his brother’s heir, and almost a man grown. “You are the Stark in the Winterfell, and Robb’s heir.” -Bran, ACOK

Bran’s suffering because of his maiming just as Winterfell itself is “broken” establishes a sympathetic link between king and kingdom.

The stone is strong, Bran told himself, the roots of the trees go deep, and under the ground the Kings of Winter sit their thrones. So long as those remained, Winterfell remained. It was not dead, just broken. Like me, he thought. I’m not dead either.

- Bran VII, ACOK

“Bran,” he said sullenly. Bran the Broken. “Brandon Stark.” The cripple boy. “The Prince of Winterfell.”

- Bran I, ASOS

Bran becomes a reflection of Winterfell itself, he’s tied himself to its broken state - as a king ties himself to its land. But as Bran the Builder built Winterfell from its stone and drew power from its heart tree, so will Bran as the heir to the winter throne. Which is something to remember, btw. The show chose not to emphasize the fact Bran is very aware of his responsibility as Robb’s heir and it’s something the Reeds are always careful to remind him of: I’m the Prince of the North, and a warg too.-(Bran, ASOS) “You are our prince as well, our lord’s son, and our king’s true heir.” -(Meera Reed to Bran, ASOS) Jojen gazed up at him with his dark green eyes. “There’s nothing here to hurt us, Your Grace.”-(Bran, ASOS) “He’s our prince.”-(Meera to Samwell Tarly, ASOS) “By night all cloaks are black, Your Grace.”-(Jojen to Bran, ASOS) Every Stark except Bran has other people manipulating their names to claim the Northern throne. Baelish wants to see Sansa as Queen, the Northern Lords are rallying behind Rickon, and Arya’s name was used by the Boltons to consolidate their rule over Winterfell. What’s fascinating is that the true heir to the North, the only one out of the four surviving trueborn Starks to ever rule Winterfell, is the one who’s excluded from this game of thrones and far in the lands the Starks originated from, deep in Winter and learning the magic rooted in Stark ancestry - warging, the Old Gods, and the powers of the weirwood trees. Bran embodies the North and House Stark, it’s only fitting that he should be the one to rule it in the end. Also regardless of the show, the North is patriarchal af and would never support a woman ruling them, regardless of how “broken” Bran may appear. He’s the male heir to the throne and that’s enough for every House to support his claim. The Fisher King theory has resurfaced again after the show’s ending, but it’s important to emphasise if you’ve read it that it contradicts Bran becoming King of Westeros and even more so for something as petty as politics, because it makes an explicit magical connection between Bran and Winterfell. With the return of magic to the world, this connection becomes important for the Stark survival as the game of thrones becomes part of the old world order that’s crumbling, taking all the players with it. Unless Winterfell becomes the centre of power for the entire continent (unlikely) Bran’s set up to be KITN and to carry on the Stark legacy.

I disagree with the implication the theory makes that Bran ends up like a tree, though the Fisher King was physically tied to the land as one would be by merging with a weirwood tree. That’s literally Bran’s nightmare, and while the show’s turned him into a weird robot, Bran has a remarkable capacity for love and compassion which we’ve seen when he ruled Winterfell so he’s more than capable of being a very sweet and kind king. Fun fact: the Fisher King has also been compared to Bran the Blessed, the legendary King who also wins the Holy Grail and saves his sister who was married to an evil foreign king who abuses her. This sister was called the White Raven, and sent messages to her brother using ‘little birds.’ Sounds a lot like Sansa’s story from the original outline, where she was married to Joffrey and similarly mistreated. Bran Stark, the Fisher King, and Bran the Builder The Fisher King theory also brings up the potential connection between the Starks and the Others, but more importantly, establishes a connection with the man who founded House Stark and was the first King of Winter - Bran the Builder: Understanding that the Builder as the Fisher King resolves many contradictions in his story, namely the idea that a man went to a race of beings who made their homes from wood and leaf to learn how to a build a stone castle. There was a purpose much beyond learning; he went to propose a union: human civilization and primordial forest, to create a monolith that is both castle and tree, ruled by a man that is both king and shaman, as it was meant to be. And as it will be, by the only king in Westeros that GRRM and his story values and honors: Brandon Stark, the heir to Winterfell, son of Lord Eddard and Lady Catelyn. Our Bran has potential parallels with the first King of his name too:

“Yet someday he may be the lord of a great holdfast and sit on the king’s council. He might raise castles like Brandon the Builder, or sail a ship across the Sunset Sea, or enter your mother’s faith and become a High Septon.”

- Eddard V, AGOT Ned tells Arya that while Bran would never be a knight, he could raise a castle like their ancestor. In the show’s video of the history of Westeros, narrated by Isaac Hempstead Wright himself, Bran the Builder is portrayed as being carried onto a platform, and several people have theorised that he was wheelchair-bound like our Bran is too. Another passage of note is in Clash of Kings when Durran is said to raise a seventh castle, the largest of them all, and that he was directed to do so by a small boy, one who would Bran the Builder someday. At such a young age, he showed initiative and leadership, much like Bran Stark did when he was Lord of Winterfell in his brother’s absence. Moreover, Bran the Builder built the Wall after the first great battle with the Others with the help of giants, and is said to have known the Children of the Forest. Bran has an established relationship with Leaf, the last of the Children, and has a very important part to play regarding the invasion by the Others (yeah fuck the show, it wasted his potential) because it’s always been part of House Stark’s destiny to protect the realm from them: The Others are the wolves to hunt humans, the ice to bring balance to the fire. The Starks in Winterfell act as one of the keepers of that balance, the lock on a gate that keeps at bay a dark power in the earth. Bran is the Stark carrying on the first King of Winter’s legacy by allying with the Children of the Forest and having a front seat to the looming War for the Dawn, and as the show demonstrated, is the key to humanity’s survival. That’s not a show invention, his training is leading up to something far bigger than anything we’ve seen before. And as Brandon Stark’s heir to protecting the realm, it’s only fitting that he gains the crown his ancestor wore as well.

Unless Winterfell becomes the centre of power for the entire continent (unlikely) Bran’s set up to be KITN and to carry on the Stark legacy.

I disagree with the implication the theory makes that Bran ends up like a tree, though the Fisher King was physically tied to the land as one would be by merging with a weirwood tree. That’s literally Bran’s nightmare, and while the show’s turned him into a weird robot, Bran has a remarkable capacity for love and compassion which we’ve seen when he ruled Winterfell so he’s more than capable of being a very sweet and kind king. Fun fact: the Fisher King has also been compared to Bran the Blessed, the legendary King who also wins the Holy Grail and saves his sister who was married to an evil foreign king who abuses her. This sister was called the White Raven, and sent messages to her brother using ‘little birds.’ Sounds a lot like Sansa’s story from the original outline, where she was married to Joffrey and similarly mistreated. Bran Stark, the Fisher King, and Bran the Builder The Fisher King theory also brings up the potential connection between the Starks and the Others, but more importantly, establishes a connection with the man who founded House Stark and was the first King of Winter - Bran the Builder: Understanding that the Builder as the Fisher King resolves many contradictions in his story, namely the idea that a man went to a race of beings who made their homes from wood and leaf to learn how to a build a stone castle. There was a purpose much beyond learning; he went to propose a union: human civilization and primordial forest, to create a monolith that is both castle and tree, ruled by a man that is both king and shaman, as it was meant to be. And as it will be, by the only king in Westeros that GRRM and his story values and honors: Brandon Stark, the heir to Winterfell, son of Lord Eddard and Lady Catelyn. Our Bran has potential parallels with the first King of his name too:

“Yet someday he may be the lord of a great holdfast and sit on the king’s council. He might raise castles like Brandon the Builder, or sail a ship across the Sunset Sea, or enter your mother’s faith and become a High Septon.”

- Eddard V, AGOT Ned tells Arya that while Bran would never be a knight, he could raise a castle like their ancestor. In the show’s video of the history of Westeros, narrated by Isaac Hempstead Wright himself, Bran the Builder is portrayed as being carried onto a platform, and several people have theorised that he was wheelchair-bound like our Bran is too. Another passage of note is in Clash of Kings when Durran is said to raise a seventh castle, the largest of them all, and that he was directed to do so by a small boy, one who would Bran the Builder someday. At such a young age, he showed initiative and leadership, much like Bran Stark did when he was Lord of Winterfell in his brother’s absence. Moreover, Bran the Builder built the Wall after the first great battle with the Others with the help of giants, and is said to have known the Children of the Forest. Bran has an established relationship with Leaf, the last of the Children, and has a very important part to play regarding the invasion by the Others (yeah fuck the show, it wasted his potential) because it’s always been part of House Stark’s destiny to protect the realm from them: The Others are the wolves to hunt humans, the ice to bring balance to the fire. The Starks in Winterfell act as one of the keepers of that balance, the lock on a gate that keeps at bay a dark power in the earth. Bran is the Stark carrying on the first King of Winter’s legacy by allying with the Children of the Forest and having a front seat to the looming War for the Dawn, and as the show demonstrated, is the key to humanity’s survival. That’s not a show invention, his training is leading up to something far bigger than anything we’ve seen before. And as Brandon Stark’s heir to protecting the realm, it’s only fitting that he gains the crown his ancestor wore as well.
trail.content:
Bran becoming King is something I’ve always considered, but now I’m confident he becomes King in the North in the books.

If we take the show-verse, then yeah, it’s completely out of nowhere.

But the books carry just enough hints and foreshadowing that we can see how this becomes his endgame. But again, his throne is in the North.

The Fisher King

There was a theory posted ages ago about Bran as “The Fisher King.” I suggest a read, it’s a little long to paste here but I’ll try to summarise the key points that I think are relevant. Everything in italics is quoted from the original meta. The theory highlights parallels between mythical figures and the sources of their power. For the Fisher King (or King Arthur, who GRRM has compared Bran to), who draws his powers from the Holy Grail, the Starks’ are centred around the heart tree, around Winterfell.

“The Stark in Winterfell” is ASOIAF’s incarnation of the Fisher King, a legendary figure from English and Welsh mythology who is spiritually and physically tied to the land, and whose fortunes, good and ill, are mirrored in the realm. It is a story that, as it tells how the king is maimed and then healed by divine power, validates that monarchy. The role of “The Stark in Winterfell” is meant to be as its creator Brandon the Builder was, a fusion of apparent opposites: man and god, king and greenseer, and the monolith that is his seat is both castle and tree, a “monstrous stone tree.”

And it’s not just any Stark - the Stark in Winterfell is a title interchangeable with the one that rules it: “The Stark in Winterfell wanted Bael’s head…” “The Stark in Winterfell had to take a hand [in-stopping the Night’s Watch’s rebellion] -Jon, ASOS And then you’ve got Bran, who’s repeatedly referred as such. “I’m the Prince. I’m the Stark in Winterfell.” “You are the Stark in Winterfell, and Robb’s heir. You must look princely.” Together they garbed him as befit a lord. He was the Stark in Winterfell, his father’s son and his brother’s heir, and almost a man grown. “You are the Stark in the Winterfell, and Robb’s heir.” -Bran, ACOK

Bran’s suffering because of his maiming just as Winterfell itself is “broken” establishes a sympathetic link between king and kingdom.

The stone is strong, Bran told himself, the roots of the trees go deep, and under the ground the Kings of Winter sit their thrones. So long as those remained, Winterfell remained. It was not dead, just broken. Like me, he thought. I’m not dead either.

- Bran VII, ACOK

“Bran,” he said sullenly. Bran the Broken. “Brandon Stark.” The cripple boy. “The Prince of Winterfell.”

- Bran I, ASOS

Bran becomes a reflection of Winterfell itself, he’s tied himself to its broken state - as a king ties himself to its land. But as Bran the Builder built Winterfell from its stone and drew power from its heart tree, so will Bran as the heir to the winter throne. Which is something to remember, btw. The show chose not to emphasize the fact Bran is very aware of his responsibility as Robb’s heir and it’s something the Reeds are always careful to remind him of: I’m the Prince of the North, and a warg too.-(Bran, ASOS) “You are our prince as well, our lord’s son, and our king’s true heir.” -(Meera Reed to Bran, ASOS) Jojen gazed up at him with his dark green eyes. “There’s nothing here to hurt us, Your Grace.”-(Bran, ASOS) “He’s our prince.”-(Meera to Samwell Tarly, ASOS) “By night all cloaks are black, Your Grace.”-(Jojen to Bran, ASOS) Every Stark except Bran has other people manipulating their names to claim the Northern throne. Baelish wants to see Sansa as Queen, the Northern Lords are rallying behind Rickon, and Arya’s name was used by the Boltons to consolidate their rule over Winterfell. What’s fascinating is that the true heir to the North, the only one out of the four surviving trueborn Starks to ever rule Winterfell, is the one who’s excluded from this game of thrones and far in the lands the Starks originated from, deep in Winter and learning the magic rooted in Stark ancestry - warging, the Old Gods, and the powers of the weirwood trees. Bran embodies the North and House Stark, it’s only fitting that he should be the one to rule it in the end. Also regardless of the show, the North is patriarchal af and would never support a woman ruling them, regardless of how “broken” Bran may appear. He’s the male heir to the throne and that’s enough for every House to support his claim. The Fisher King theory has resurfaced again after the show’s ending, but it’s important to emphasise if you’ve read it that it contradicts Bran becoming King of Westeros and even more so for something as petty as politics, because it makes an explicit magical connection between Bran and Winterfell. I disagree with the implication the theory makes that Bran ends up like a tree, though the Fisher King was physically tied to the land as one would be by merging with a weirwood tree. summary:
People get angry at Sophie for sharing her tattoo of the pack survives and 'spoiling' the ending and I'm like: 
Dude, my doods....
body:
People get angry at Sophie for sharing her tattoo of the pack survives and ‘spoiling’ the ending and I’m like:

Dude, my doods. Did you really think that Starks wouldn’t survive up at this point of the story? Did you really think that the family that suffered the most, the first and only one we follow from the start as the good guys, would end with all of them dying? Wow, d&d really made you think that this was a Dany show 😂

body:
remember when everyone was worried about lady hornwood and ramsay and the other northern lords sniffing around and she didn’t feel safe

and 8 year old bran was like

and nobody listened and then like 2 weeks later ramsay got ahold of lady hornwood and forced her into marriage and eventual death and the northern lords was line oH My God how could this have HAPPENED, adding to the growing list of northern grievances that could’ve actually been resolved pretty early on
